Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Use of Narrative Enhancement to Facilitate Children's Productivity in Eyewitness Testimony

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research concerning children's eyewitness abilities has repeatedly demonstrated harmful effects of suggestive questioning and superior accuracy of free-recall reports. However, children's free recall is often incomplete, and new interview methods are needed that enhance children's productivity without increasing contamination. In the current research, we are examining whether several very simple and easily implemented interviewer behaviors can do just this. Such behaviors include vocatives (e.g., stating the child's name), which focus the child's attention; and back-channel utterances (e.g., following responses with "uh huh"), which convey interviewer attentiveness. These behaviors have been observed in field research of forensic interviews. However, because ground truth is not known and there is no control over the use of the behaviors in naturalistic settings, the actual effects of these behaviors on productivity and accuracy are unknown. We are experimentally testing the effects of these interviewer behaviors, collectively referred to as facilitative utterances, on 4- to 9-year olds' descriptions of a salient event, namely a laboratory activity involving a minor transgression (toy breakage). Our procedures will allow us to determine whether facilitative utterances increase how much children report about prior experiences, particularly those that include some negative components, and whether the benefits of facilitative utterances vary with age, for example, as children become more competent recounting past events without assistance from others.

Overall, our project will advance science and policy at the interface of developmental psychology and the law. Considerable uncertainty remains about how best to elicit detailed narrative reports from suspected child victims. Much of this uncertainty is attributable to a lack of experimental investigation of interviewer behaviors commonly observed in field practices. By conducting a systematic assessment of potentially critical interviewer behaviors, we will be able to decrease some of this uncertainty, thereby improving the identification of truly abused children and the legal system's ability to pursue justice in cases involving alleged abuse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

A great deal of research concerning children’s eyewitness abilities has demonstrated the harmful effects of suggestive questioning and superior accuracy of children’s free-recall reports.  However, research has also demonstrated that children’s free recall reports are often incomplete, and little research has addressed how children’s reports can be enhanced without increasing errors. In this collaborative project, we examined how specific behavior of an interviewer (beyond the questions themselves) affects children’s memory completeness and accuracy. The behaviors we studied included back-channel utterances (e.g., “uh huh”), often used naturally when in conversations, and vocatives (child’s name), which direct children’s attention toward the interviewer. Collectively, these are called facilitators. We tested the effects of facilitators in two related studies.

Studies and Outcomes

In the first study, 3-9 year olds engaged in an interactive activity with a Baker who visited their class. He showed children how to make cookies during which a mishap occurred (salt spilled), ruining the cookie dough. One- to two-weeks later, children were interviewed about what happened. Initially, children were asked questions about both true and false details. The interviewer reinforced children for agreeing with the false details and expressed disappointment when children corrected the interviewer. High numbers of children erred, although with age, children’s errors decreased. Also, the older children were less likely to err when questions suggested they did something wrong (e.g., that they yelled at someone) than when questions suggested they did something positive (e.g., they helped clean). Younger children’s errors did not differ depending on the emotional valence of the suggestions. A second unfamiliar interviewer then questioned children. For half, she included facilitators throughout the interviews. Facilitators indeed increased how much children said.  Moreover, children did not incorporate false details from the first interview into their second interview, and facilitators did not affect children’s accuracy. Thus, facilitators were helpful.

Because the study concerned children’s reports of a positive activity (though some of the suggestions were negative), with supplemental funding from NSF, we investigated whether facilitators emerged naturally when children describe negative experiences. We reviewed actual forensic interviews of suspected victims of physical or sexual abuse for facilitator occurrences. We coded redacted interviews for (a) back-channel utterances, (b) children’s response productivity after the utterance, and (c) what was said before the back-channel utterance was stated. (We attempted to code for vocatives, but these were too rare.) We compared children’s statements before and after back-channel utterances to test for order effects (i.e, to see whether back-channel utterances were more likely to follow or lead to lengthy statements from children. This helps disentangle causality-an important issue when trying to develop recommendations from studies to give to forensic interviewers. Our findings, though preliminary, suggest that interviewers use back-channel utterances quite frequently in interviews. Sometimes they increase how much children say, but other times, they seem to stop children from talking. We are now in the process of examining when one versus the other occurs, again a critical issue in terms of developing recommendations.
